chapter.title: Sessions
chapter.para: This chapter discusses Ardour sessions in more detail.

section.title: Sessions, session files and snapshots
section.para: Generally speaking when we talk about an Ardour ‘session’ we mean a directory that contains everything related to the session: all Ardour's data and the sound files.

A session consists of two main things. Firstly, we have the session state file: this is Ardour's description of what happens in the session. It contains lists of tracks, regions, what sound files are used, automation data, the connections between things, and so on. It does not, however, contain any audio or MIDI data. These data are kept separately, in their own files, using standard formats.
The session state file is stored on disk with the suffix .ardour.

It is eminently possible that we might have more than one session state file describing a different arrangement of the same sound files. Perhaps there is a mix that was sent to a client, and a new mix that you are working on, and you want to be able to refer back to the old mix. Alternatively, perhaps you are about to try something drastic with a session, and it would make sense to keep an old copy of the session just in case you change your mind. Ardour can manage these situations using snapshots.

A snapshot is simply a session state file. A particular session directory may contain many snapshots, each looking at the same set of audio and MIDI data and describing a different arrangement of the raw data.

section.title: Taking and switching between snapshots
section.para: To make a snapshot of the current state of a session, simply choose Snapshot… from the Session menu or press &modtertiary;&modone;S. This will open a dialogue box for you to give the name of the new snapshot; the name is initially filled in with the current date and time. Clicking Save will create the snapshot.

To look at the snapshots of the current session, open the editor list and select the Snapshots tab. The list will show the existing snapshots, with a blue highlight on the current one. Clicking on an alternate snapshot will switch to it.
You can rename or remove snapshots by right-clicking on their names in the editor list and choosing an option from the menu.
Edits that you make to the session are always saved to the current snapshot.
